Honey, disconnect the phone

In those days, spying was sometimes done by rigging the telephone and listening to whatever was happening in the room through it’s microphone; this was called wiretapping. However, disconnecting it would disconnect the link to the listener – concealable battery-powered wireless transmitters weren’t developed yet.
Because the USSR was an adversary of Britain (the Beatles were British!), they might’ve wiretapped the telephone in their hotel room.

Been away so long, I hardly knew the place
 Gee, it’s good to be back home

The period after Stalin’s death brought the ‘Khrushchev Thaw’: the first secretary of the time, Nikita Khrushchev, introduced a series of reforms which would bring an end to the claustrophobic and xenophobic Soviet life under the Stalinist regime. The culmination of the ‘thaw’ even saw the Beatlemania arriving in Russia.



Above: Khrushchev, happily posing with the corn

However, Khrushchev was ousted from power the next year, in 1965, and replaced with Leonid Brezhnev. Although in many ways a protégé of Khrushchev, Brezhnev promptly ended the reforms; and, among other things, approved the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, at the time The Beatles recorded the song.



Above: Brezhnev’s ‘Blue Steel’ look

As for the rest of the world, for The Beatles, the change must have been palpable: Perhaps that’s why the narrator hardly recognizes the place anymore.
I’m back in the U.S.S.R

When the song was first being played the USSR was a hard topic to breach in the UK and USA – it was recorded around the time the Soviets were invading Czechoslovakia. Making a song about the communist country was considered quite brave by some, while others like the John Birch Society accused them of “fomenting Communism”.

The song gained an underground popularity in the USSR, however, smuggled in on bootleg tapes.
Back in the U.S.S.R.​

On the other hand, when Paul really played in the former Soviet Union, with a concert in Moscow’s Red Square, many a jokey title related to this song appeared.

Back in the U.S
 Back in the U.S

This part (where the split from the abbreviation of “United States” to the one for “Union of Soviet Socialist Republics” is probably intentional) later baptized the Paul McCartney solo release Back in the U.S. (2002), marking his first tour in nearly a decade.
Take me to your daddy’s farm

Although in those days, the Soviet government took over all agricultural lands.



Plus, private ownership is disallowed in Marxism, so “daddy’s farm” would never be able to exist in any Communist state, the USSR included.
Oh show me round your snow-peaked mountains way down south

This is a reference to the Caucasus Mountains in southern Russia.



 …or it’s a clever way of saying “show me your breasts.”  Really both.
They leave the West behind

“The West” refers to the area west of the Iron Curtain, which roughly corresponds with the United States’s ideologically-aligned allies. The U.S.S.R. was to the east of the curtain.



“The West” can also be interpreted as the western United States, and the line becomes a cheeky response to the Beach Boys' “California Girls,” which praises West Coast girls as the best in America.

I wish they all could be California girls

McCartney replies that the Soviet girls surpass even the very best girls America has to offer.

You don’t know how lucky you are, boy
 Back in the U.S.S.R.

I just liked the idea of Georgia girls and talking about places like the Ukraine as if they were California, you know? It was also hands across the water, which I’m still conscious of. ‘Cause they like us out there, even though the bosses in the Kremlin may not. The kids from there do. And that to me is very important for the future of the race.
- Paul McCartney 

The narrator of the song is as happy to be back in chilly Russia as an American would be happy to be back in sunny Cali (as the Beach Boys would frequently sing).
Come and keep your comrade warm

Comrade can mean friend, colleague, or ally.  However, in Soviet Russia the term was used to address a fellow Marxist (Communist).

Most likely refers to keeping Paul warm in the sheets.
